FIGREF3.text: Figure 23.4: Bronchiole-associated lymphoid tissue (asterisk) adjacent to the airway (A).

FIGREF4.text: Figure 23.5: External oblique muscle (arrow) surrounding a right-angle branch artery. This is a unique feature of the rat pulmonary vasculature.

FIGREF5.text: Figure 23.6: Myocardial cells (arrows) surrounding a pulmonary vein.

FIGREF6.text: Figure 23.7: Subpleural cyst (asterisk) with mild fibrosis (arrow) in the cyst wall.

FIGREF7.text: Figure 23.8: Infiltrates of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages in the rat lung infected with Pneumocystis carinii. Note characteristic dense perivascular (asterisks) accumulation of the infiltrating cells.

FIGREF8.text: Figure 23.9: Bronchiolar epithelial necrosis characterized by pyknosis, karyorrhexis and sloughing, and loss of epithelium (arrow)

FIGREF9.text: Figure 23.10: Pleural fibrosis (arrows) adjacent to an area of subpleural chronic inflammation in the lung of rat exposed to particulate by inflammation. Note fibrous thickening of the alveolar interstitium within the area of inflammation.

FIGREF10.text: Figure 23.11: Alveolar proteinosis with amorphous eosinophilic material within the alveoli.

FIGREF11.text: Figure 23.12:  Alveolar histiocytosis consisting of macrophages with foamy cytoplasm within the alveoli.

FIGREF12.text: Figure 23.13: Following inhalation exposure to particulates where there is marked proteinosis, the alveolar macrophages may contain intracytoplasmic crystalline material.

FIGREF13.text: Figure 23.14: Mineralization of the alveolar septa (arrows).

FIGREF14.text: Figure 23.15: Hemosiderin pigment (arrow) in the lung appears as golden yellow material within macrophages in an area of mononuclear cell infiltration.

FIGREF15.text: Figure 23.16: Regeneration of the bronchiolar epithelium. Note flattered epithelium lining the airway (arrow).

FIGREF16.text: Figure 23.17: Hyperplasia of the bronchiolar epithelium. Note crowding of the epithelium (arrows).

FIGREF17.text: Figure 23.18: Alveolar hyperplasia of the Type II alveolar epithelium characterized by an increase in Type II epithelial cells (asterisk). The underlying alveolar architecture is preserved.

FIGREF18.text: Figure 23.19: Higher magnification of Fig. 23.18. Cuboidal Type II epithelial cells line the alveolar septa. Note increased numbers of macrophages (alveolar histiocytosis) within the alveoli.

FIGREF19.text: Figure 23.20: Replacement of the alveolar epithelium with ciliated hyperplastic cells (arrow). Note also that the alveolar epithelium is replaced by irregular areas of squamous epithelium (asterisks), a common finding in cases of ongoing prolonged damage.

FIGREF20.text: Figure 23.21: Focal alveolar epithelial hyperplasia. The alveolar architecture is essentially maintained, however, there is early distortion.

FIGREF21.text: Figure 23.22: Higher magnification of Fig. 23.21. The alveoli are lined by round to cuboidal hyperplastic cells and there is focal piling up and distortion of the hyperplastic epithelium. Note increased numbers of macrophages within the alveoli.

FIGREF22.text: Figure 23.23: Hyperplasia of the bronchiolar epithelium. The hyperplastic cells form papillary projections into the lumen (L).

FIGREF23.text: Figure 23.24: Mesothelial cell hyperplasia characterized by hyperplasia and hypertrophy of the mesothelial cells lining the pleura (arrows). Also note the subpleural fibrosis (asterisk).

FIGREF24.text: Figure 23.25: Mesothelial hyperplasia occurs as micropapillary fronds of connective tissue lined by a single layer of flat to low cuboidal mesothelial cells. Note pleural fibrosis.

FIGREF25.text: Figure 23.26: Alveolar/bronchiolar adenoma. The alveolar architecture is largely effaced but is still visible in some areas.

FIGREF26.text: Figure 23.27: Higher magnification of Fig. 23.26. The alveolar/bronchiolar adenoma has a papillary pattern.

FIGREF27.text: Figure 23.28: Alveolar/bronchiolar adenoma. The alveolar architecture is completely effaced.

FIGREF28.text: Figure 23.29: Higher magnification of Fig 23.28. Note the distinct papillary growth pattern.

FIGREF29.text: Figure 23.30: Alveolar/bronchiolar carcinoma that is highly invasive and expansive and has largely effaced the lung parenchyma.

FIGREF30.text: Figure 23.31: Higher magnification of Fig. 23.30. Note the distinct papillary pattern characterized by well- to poorly-defined papillary structures lined by pleomorphic neoplastic cells. In some areas, the papillary structures are supported by irregular strands of fibrous stroma.

FIGREF31.text: Figure 23.32: Alveolar/bronchiolar carcinoma showing compression of the immediately adjacent lung parenchyma.

FIGREF32.text: Figure 23.33: Higher magnification of Fig. 23.32. Note glandular growth pattern and solid sheets of cells. Gland-like structures are separated by thin fibrovascular stroma.

FIGREF33.text: Figure 23.34: Highly invasive alveolar/bronchiolar carcinoma showing invasion into the airway (asterisk).

FIGREF34.text: Figure 23.35: Higher magnification of Fig. 23.34. Note poorly defined glandular and papillary pattern and the schirrous component.

FIGREF35.text: Figure 23.36: Alveolar/bronchiolar carcinoma with a heterogeneous growth pattern and a scirrhous component (asterisk).

FIGREF36.text: Figure 23.37: Higher magnification of Fig. 23.36. Note heterogeneous growth and anaplastic, pleomorphic cells interspersed with irregular bands of fibrous tissue.

FIGREF37.text: Figure 23.38: Alveolar/bronchiolar carcinoma with anaplastic spindle cell component.

FIGREF38.text: Figure 23.39: Alveolar/bronchiolar carcinoma with papillary and tubular pattern of growth on the left and squamous differentiation on the right.

FIGREF39.text: Figure 23.40: Bronchial carcinoma. Note exophytic papillary growth of the neoplastic epithelial cells in the lumen of the bronchus, and invasion into the peribronchial submucosal tissue.

FIGREF41.text: Figure 23.42: Bronchial carcinoma. The neoplastic epithelium (arrows) has invaded the wall of the bronchus.

FIGREF42.text: Figure 23.43: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

FIGREF43.text: Figure 23.44: Higher magnification of Fig. 23.43. Note irregular bands of neoplastic squamous epithelium interspersed with necrotic epithelial cells.

FIGREF44.text: Figure 23.45: Cystic keratinizing epithelioma in the lung. Note central, cystic cavity that contains laminated keratin and keratin whorls (pearls), surrounded by a complex wall of squamous epithelium.

FIGREF45.text: Figure 23.46: Higher magnification of Fig. 23.45. The wall is composed of well-differentiated squamous epithelium.

FIGREF46.text: Figure 23.47: Fibrosarcoma of the lung composed haphazardly arranged spindle cells.

FIGREF47.text: Figure 23.48: Malignant mesothelioma of the lung characterized by multifocal papillary neoplastic mesothelial cells on the surface of the pleura.

FIGREF48.text: Figure 23.49: Higher magnification of Fig. 23.48. Note characteristic multiple, frond-like proliferations lined by a single layer of uniformly small, low cuboidal to polyhedral mesothelial cells associated with fibrous thickening of the pleura.

FIGREF49.text: Figure 23.50: Alveolar/bronchiolar carcinoma invading the mediastinum of the lung.

FIGREF50.text: Figure 23.51: Higher magnification of Fig. 23.50. Note that the neoplasm consists of distinctly papillary structures composed a delicate vascularized stroma lined uniformly cuboidal neoplastic cells with apical cytoplasmic vacuoles reminiscent of alveolar Type II cells.

FIGREF51.text: Figure 23.52: Mononuclear cell leukemia in the rat lung. Note lymphocytes within blood vessels and capillaries.

FIGREF52.text: Figure 23.53: Gavage-related lesion in the lung. Note golden yellow gavage vehicle (oil) within the lung associated chronic inflammation, hemorrhage, and congestion.

FIGREF53.text: Figure 23.54: Osseous metaplasia in the lung consisting of irregular clusters of woven bone.
